intro: Endosiphon obliquus, commonly known as the slender marsh sedge, is a flowering plant species belonging to the family Cyperaceae. It is characterized by its grass-like appearance, with narrow, linear leaves and small, clustered flower heads. The plant typically grows in wet or marshy habitats, preferring moist soils and full sun to partial shade. Its reproductive structures are adapted for wind pollination, which is common among sedges. Endosiphon obliquus plays a role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various invertebrates.
